Definition: You have been given a comment from some user from the dataset of civil comment, categorize the comment on the basis of obscenity of comment. If the comment is obscene output Yes, otherwise output No.

Positive Examples.input: Will this remove the property from city taxes?
Positive Examples.explanation: The comment here is just a normal question without any indecent words and categorized as not obscene. Hence, it is a positive example
The comment uses immoral and indecent words and is categorized as obscene. Therefore, this is a positive example.

Negative Examples.explanation: The comment is abbreviation of indecent word, but classified as not obscene. Therefore, this is a negative example.
The comment has '*' in an indecent remark which makes it to be classified as not obscene, while the word 'shitty' should be classified as obscene. Therefore, this is a negative example.

About a month later, I happened to visit his residence & saw the mistake; first thought I spoke aloud: 'What happens when you're miles away & batteries run flat?' He said nothing in reply.

A month after that, I spoke to him; he was not doing well at all. Seems the 'electric-bike' left him miles from home, dead battery; required him to push it four hours via bike path. Took him four months to recover from the 'non-pedal' event.

The battery/bike killed him!

I fully get your point.  Balance to you means folks that are not consumptive users of game.  Yet you assume that the board of game controls the entire F&G budget and gets all the money.  It does not.  Those funds are disbursed throughout their budget for other things like habitat restoration, research, shooting ranges, etc., many things that have nothing to do with the Board of Game.  So your point is invalid.  If you want to have a voice in how shooters funds are used, feel free to call F&G, or your local Advisory Council.

But make no mistake, the reason that F&G does get those matching funds is directly due to the fact that they have to match those funds with hunting and fishing license fees and those hunting and fishing fees must stay within F&G.  So you can whine all you want about shooters, but the fact is those funds come to F&G due to hunters and fishermen, yet help shooters, boaters, viewers, and campers as well.

This bill, in its present form, is a compromise.  A somewhat surprising coalition passed it.  A big enough coalition that if the Senate refuses to go along, probably there will be a budget crisis writ large.  The one great merit of this compromise is that it isn't a total change and it allows time for companies, the state and individuals to adjust.  Never mind what fiscal conservatives (including me) would prefer on principle, it is probably wiser to proceed in a more deliberate way, spending some of the state's savings for a few years.  Not to start down this road would be a grand strategic error.  I am far more impressed with the legislature this year than last year.  Or I will be if the Senate manages to act on this in a meaningful way.

Chase, with all due respect, it might be you that does not understand the mining law of 1872. the law established rights to claims and established prices for the lands those claims were set on. it in no way established responsibility for cleanup, but rather established the method or how claims were processed. this prevented "claim jumping" and established who owned what and where. a claim had to spend a certain amount of money each year, if memory serves it was $100 annually. after showing this for a period of time, 5 years I believe, they could apply for a patent on that claim, by which the miner would then own that land. thus the term "patented claim" versus "unpatented claim". now, if the miner filed a claim that was never patented then the land would revert back to federal control. the government in  1977 passed the Surface Control and Reclamation Act (SMCRA) to ensure that mining companies would restore the lands after the mining. more to come.

Congressman Young facilitated federal restrictions on how passenger fees could be spent in a measure related to port security back in 2002, or thereabouts.  The federal law provisions do not make the fees collected by a local government a "dedicated fund" contrary to the Alaska Constitution but they do limit the allocation of funds to projects or activities that promote the "safety" and "efficiency" of cruise vessel passengers.  Obviously using the funds to construct a large passenger wharf is sanctioned by federal law.  Using the funds for activities unrelated to safe and efficient movement of cruise passengers would violate the law.  Whether using funds for a park that will be used, in part, by passengers is an open question, at this point.  As this lawsuit is decided, it is worth noting that the fees in question are paid for by the passengers, not the cruise lines.  Do the cruise lines even have standing to challenge the fees being collected from passengers and not the cruise lines!

Scott Coltrane's claim the U of O " historically avoided classes on Friday" doesn't fact check very well.  Friday classes were in big supply until the mid 90's when the faculty at the Business school decided they wanted three-day weekends.  

It didn't take long for the academics in all the other departments to ask "Why am I dealing with these kids every Friday?  Where's MY 3 day weekend?"  The Friday sessions gradually disappeared and the teachers dealt with classes just twice a week.

The archived class schedules, going back decades, are on the UO website.  It's impossible to miss the trend as it evolved.  Claiming the students didn't want to drag off to class on Friday is bogus.

Hi David, we did consider all of these possibilities when building our system! In fact, we assume people will try to game it; that's why we have a lot going on behind the scenes algorithmically. The commenter-facing part of the app is very straightforward, but there are a lot of checks and balances on the backend to prevent coordinated attacks and also to keep comments sections from becoming echo chambers. Banning insulting words isn't enough, unfortunately; people will always be smarter than word filters, even if the algorithm tries to take context into account. We do have a backup algorithm for low-volume situations that basically does this (plus a few other things), but it's not as effective as human reviewers.

I hear you on the "more replies" button; I don't think we'll remove it entirely, but I agree it's appearing too often, after too few comments. We'll be pushing updates very soon!

Time accounting is a major headache for anyone who done for DOC Alaska. I did it for quite a while back in the 1980s and bit of 90s. I can say this much, this is extremely time consuming process of anal paperwork and counting down the exact dates plus reading court paperwork where the judges gives certain instructions on when or where if the inmate deserves or not deserves any prior service time or on what case. This is a Byzantine nightmare of misplaced files and papers. To make it worst, often come with court orders that contradict itself or poorly written. And the court paperwork are never timely and plea deals make some inmates being released months after their actual release dates after all the calculation are done. If the inmate is in for Probation Violation, then you have to reboot the calculations. Often only one person is handling this for hundreds of cases and when I was doing it, and this was when we were well staffed, I was still required to help out with other duties.

In many "rape" situations there is no question that intercourse has occurred and no question about who the parties involved are.  Often times the "victim" and "perp" agree on identities and that intercourse has occurred.  The presence or absence of criminal action hangs not on physical fact but on consent or lack thereof.  In such situations, rape kits provide no material evidence.  While DA's are compelled to turn over exculpatory evidence (not that they actually do anyway), they have no particular requirements on how they investigate a case.  Nowhere in the constitution are rape kits mentioned.  Unless legislation has been passed to require a rape kit for every sexual transgression, there is no mandate that one be obtained.   While we as a society should ensure that solid investigation into every rape allegation is conducted, each situation is different and rape kits are not always material in any way.  I suggest that conviction hungry DA's already process rape kits when material.
